creator: Spence, Thomas, 1832-1900. (author)
description: Spence, Thomas: 1832-1900. From England to Canada, 1862; to Red River, 1866; became involved in local politics, and instrumental in calling a meeting favouring union with Canada; later a prime mover in sending an invitation to the Prince of Wales from the First Nations asking him to visit; settled in Portage la Prairie, 1867; organized a provisional government, Republic of Manitoba, with himself as president, but government soon collapsed; edited The New Nation,1870; after formation of the province of Manitoba, became clerk of Legislative Council, and later of Legislative Assembly; census commissioner for NWT in 1881 and 1885; lived in California for some years engaged in immigration work; assistant registrar in Dominion land office in Edmonton, 1895-1900 (Edmonton Bulletin, March 23, 1900; Robertson, A political manual of the province of Manitoba). // Also published, revised edition, Montreal: Lovell Printing & Publishing Co., 1877 (60p.; pages 50-60 are advertisements); Montreal: Lovell Printing & Publishing Co., 1879 (59p.).

title: The Saskatchewan country of the north-west of the Dominion of Canada: Presented to the world as a new and inviting field of enterprise for the emigrant and capitalist: Its comparison as such with the western states and territories of America: Its climate, soil, agriculture, &c.: Minerals and manufacturing facilities, and the elements of its future greatness and prosperity: Points best suited for immediate settlement: Latest information, outfit, prices, &c.
